DOC.HEAD: Army Kills 43 Guerrillas in Peruvian Jungle, 1 Soldier Killed
DOC.TEXT: An army patrol attacked a jungle camp of pro-Cuban guerrillas, killing 43 and recovering a large cache of arms and supplies, officials said Tuesday. A spokesman for the military command in Lima said one army sergeant was killed and two soldiers were wounded in the battle with rebels of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement. The spokesman, who asked not to be identified, said the battle took place Sunday in a remote jungle region along the Iscozacin River, 175 miles northeast of Lima in Pasco department. The spokesman said army troops recovered arms and explosives as well as radios, medicine, tents, uniforms and food. Sunday's battle was the most serious defeat for the rebels since April 28, when an army patrol wiped out a column of 62 guerrillas on a mountain road near Jauja, 105 miles east of Lima. The guerrilla movement, which advocates a Cuban-style Marxism, has been fighting Peru's elected government since 1984. Estimates of the size of the organization range from 500 to 1,500. It is smaller and considered less violent than the Shining Path, a fanatical, Maoist guerrilla group that launched its insurgency in 1980. The government says more than 17,000 people have died in the violence since 1980, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.
